text: [Music]
I'm gonna change the way you think about
cooking brown rice the biggest gripe
about brown rice is that it takes too
long to cook which of course is true it
takes 45 minutes or so which makes it
sort of impractical if you're looking to
get dinner on the table and a half hour
but there's a great technique I've
developed that can let you put brown
rice from the table in 30 minutes or so
the key is a little bit of forethought
you take your raw brown rice the day
before the night before the morning
before three days before for that matter
and your parboil it what's that mean
means you boil it and you boil it for
ten or fifteen minutes at which point
you drain it it looks like this
partially cooked brown rice that you can
treat essentially the same as you would
white rice and I'm gonna make a more or
less standard pilaf with it right now to
show you that it'll cook in fifteen
minutes so this is a no-brainer
you have to have adequate water the rice
should be covered by a couple inches you
want to boiling away the water should be
salted and the timing you do it by
timing fifteen minutes is fine the
ingredients here quite simple the
parboiled brown rice some onion olive
oil will finish with a little parsley
and the all-important chicken stock
we're gonna cook the brown rice in the
olive oil first cook the onion in the
olive oil then add the brown rice some
salt and pepper in the stock cover that
walk away for fifteen minutes
voila as they used to say olive oil in
the pan this is a standard pilaf some
chopped onion
you can add garlic you can add herbs do
pretty much whatever you want here
keeping it very simple just to
demonstrate that the brown rice will
cook fast once it's far boil when the
onion softens a bit we dump in the
parboiled brown rice and we want to coat
every kernel with oil which is not as
hard as it sounds you cook it stirring
for a minute or so and it gets done once
that's done you add your stock which
should be warm all at once and you can
use water fruit juice a wine mixed with
stock almost any liquid you want here
the smell of brown rice cooking is so
great
one stir if the stock was warm to begin
with it's gonna come to a boil right
away turn to a simmer cover 15 minutes
maybe 20 until all the liquids absorbs
and you're done
[Music]
there are three kinds of brown rice all
brown rice is whole-grain you start with
this this is short grain brown rice so
it's like arborio of Valencia or
Japanese rice a lot of it's grown in
California and it has the same
characteristics as short grain white
rice which is to say it can be a little
sticky it can be a little creamy you can
use it for risotto it's nice stuff over
here we have long grain brown rice the
best of these just like the best long
grain white rice is basmati
so if you can find a basmati strain of
long grain brown rice you're really in
business finally there are these odd
specialty Brown Rice's and they're
called Lahani or they're called red for
sort of obvious reasons sometimes
they're black they're purple they're all
different shades of dark so those are
your three choices short grain rice
specialty rice long grain rice what they
have in common is that each of them will
take 45 minutes to an hour if you cook
them from scratch but we're not cooking
them from scratch
[Music]
so it's been 15 minutes I kid you not
liquids absorbed the rice is hot it's
done perfectly cooked with a little
forethought you cook it for a while
beforehand you finish it while you're
cooking dinner you got to try this
technique
[Music]
